the Supreme Court of the United States issued rulings in Gill v. Whitford and Benisek v. Lamone, two partisan gerrymandering challenges. In neither of these rulings did the court directly address whether a district map can be struck down as unconstitutional for giving one political party advantage over another. Instead, today's rulings were made on standing grounds (as in Gill) or procedural grounds (as in Benisek).
Gill v. Whitford: The court ruled unanimously that the plaintiffs — 12 Wisconsin Democrats who alleged that Wisconsin's state legislative district plan had been subject to an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander in violation of the First and Fourteenth Amendments — had failed to demonstrate standing to bring a complaint under Article III of the United States Constitution. Chief Justice John Roberts penned the majority opinion, in which Associate Justices Anthony Kennedy, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, Samuel Alito, Sonia Sotomayor, and Elena Kagan joined. Kagan filed a concurrence, which was joined by Ginsburg, Breyer, and Sotomayor. Associate Justice Clarence Thomas filed an opinion, joined by Associate Justice Neil Gorsuch, that concurred in part with the majority opinion and the court's judgment.
Roberts noted that the court's opinion did not address the question of whether partisan gerrymandering claims are justiciable:
In cases where a plaintiff fails to demonstrate Article III standing, we usually direct the dismissal of the plaintiff's claims. This is not the usual case. It concerns an unsettled kind of claim this Court has not agreed upon, the contours and justiciability of which are unresolved. ... We therefore remand the case to the District Court so that the plaintiffs may have an opportunity to prove concrete and particularized injuries using evidence—unlike the bulk of the evidence presented thus far—that would tend to demonstrate a burden on their individual voters. We  express no views on the merits of the plaintiffs' case.

The lower Federal Courts have been coming down on the side of the plaintiffs in these cases, which is a relatively recent development, possibly spurred by the abuse of this technique to the point where state legislatures find themselves  with near-permanent  one-party control even when the actual vote totals are against them. Thus in Wisconsin, gerrymandering produced the following results in state elections: 2012: Republicans took 48% of the vote, received 60 out of 90 seats; 2014: republicans won 52% of the popular vote, won 63 of 99 seats. Similar results in other states like Pennsylvania tend to show that these are not anomalous , and the courts seem to be taking notice. SCOTUS is extremely ill at ease inserting themselves into what is a purely political process with practices dating back to the Founding Father's times. SCOTUS does not want the federal courts to in effect become the arbiters of which party in effect controls which state. It would only further turn the Judiciary into a political branch picking winners and losers in what party controls the state delegations based upon conjecture and non-proven methods and results as was the basis for the district court ruling. This is an issue best left handled by state legislatures and voters as the political branch. This should be left to state voters via referendum and/or legislatures through whatever state constitutional amending process to deal with the issue as they see fit. Given the practice dates to the time of the Founding Fathers and they saw no role for the Federal government to intervene is clear that they intended for this issue to remain within the purview of the states and their voters within. There is already a severe imbalance of power in the United States held by un-elected, robed individuals overruling the will of voters as if they were oligarchs or gods. The last thing this nation needs is the federal judiciary becoming the arbiter of elections and political processes rather than the voters. There is no republic, nor democracy when a few, select, politically appointed (un-elected) individuals and/or a tiny minority of less than 20 be-robed citizens can wrest control of the political process from their duly elected representatives. There is a political process that address this at the federal level as well. It is called Article V of the United States Constitution. It is far past time for un-elected, political appointees to stop bypassing Article V simply because they believe it to be for a good cause and too hard to pass. It was intended that way for a reason, not the least of which was to prevent tyranny - be it by a majority or a minority.

"THE SUPREME COURT rejects about 99% of the 7,000 to 8,000 petitions that reach it each year. But when it comes to cases involving reapportionment—challenges to how states draw lines for congressional or state legislative elections—the justices can’t be quite so choosy. Congress has chipped away at the cases subject to mandatory review by the Supreme Court, but it has kept it for redistricting cases where an election looms and time is of the essence. If skewed electoral maps may need to be redrawn, a special three-judge federal court is convened to hear the case; an appeal goes right to the Supreme Court, bypassing America’s 13 circuit courts.

Based on the news from this case's oral briefings, it seems highly likely that the outcome of this case will come down to the vote of Justice Kennedy. In Vieth v. Jubelirer, Kennedy voted with the majority that partisan gerrymandering claims were non-justiciable because there was no discernible and manageable standard for "adjudicating political gerrymandering claims." He did however, acknowledge that judicially manageable standards for gerrymandering could be developed in future that would allow the court to rule on cases of political gerrymandering. The standard being argued for by the defense is what's known as the "efficiency gap"--a recently-developed metric that counts number of votes “wasted” in each election, either because they are cast for the losing candidate or because the victorious candidate did not need them to win. Will Kennedy conclude that this metric is sufficient? It's though to say. But given that he voted for the stay during oral arguments, I am going to give a slight edge towards "Yes."

At issue is (1) if the SCOTUS should intervene to ensure a level playing field and prevent disenfranchisement of voters, (2) is there a manageable way to apply some standard to assess when this extreme gerrymandering occurs (Justice Alito)? Justice Breyer suggested a possible, workable compromise: that such a test would only be applied when there is one-party control of the government, and that courts should act only when the redistricting creates an "extreme outlier" when compared to other maps. In this case, the number of opportunities would be limited - once a decade, perhaps - and only if extreme (thereby allowing the SCOTUS to avoid having to decide on the validity of social science analysis and send it back to the lower courts to decide).

 different: Here the rationale for Kennedy concurrence : 
Vieth v. Jubelirer, 541 U.S. 267  124 S. Ct. 1769 , 158 L. Ed. 2d 546, 2004 U.S. LEXIS 3233, 72 U.S.L.W. 4301, 17 Fla. L. Weekly Fed. S 237 (U.S. Apr. 28, 2004)
the plurality suggests there is no place for the First Amendment in this area. See ante, at ____, 158 L. Ed. 2d, at 568. The implication  [*315]  is that under the First Amendment any and all consideration of political interests in an apportionment would be invalid. Ibid.  [****94] ("Only an equal protection claim is before us in the present case--perhaps for the very good reason that a First Amendment claim, if it were sustained, would render unlawful all consideration of political affiliation in districting"). That misrepresents the First Amendment analysis. The inquiry is not whether political classifications were used. The inquiry instead is whether political classifications were used to burden a group's representational rights. If a court were to find that a State did impose burdens and restrictions on groups or persons by reason of their views, there would likely be a First Amendment violation, unless the State shows some compelling interest. Of course, all this depends first on courts' having available a manageable standard by which to measure the effect of the apportionment and so to conclude that  [**1798]  the State did impose a burden or restriction on the rights of a party's voters.
